file_name: Exhibit 99.1 EXECUTION VERSION METLIFE, INC. Series E Senior Component Debentures, Tranche 1, due 2018 Series E Senior Component Debentures, Tranche 2, due 2045 REMARKETING AGREEMENT August 26, 2014

perturbation.original_text: The Company will promptly cause the Trustee, the Stock Purchase Contract Agent and the Collateral Agent to give the Remarketing Agents notice of all such defaults and events of which such trustee or agent is aware.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company will endeavor to cause the Trustee, the Stock Purchase Contract Agent and the Collateral Agent to give the Remarketing Agents notice of defaults and events, if practically feasible.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'will promptly cause' to 'will endeavor to cause' and adding 'if practically feasible' introduces ambiguity and weakens the obligation to provide timely notice of defaults, potentially hindering the Remarketing Agents' ability to manage risks. This creates a gray area where the company might claim inability to fulfill the notification requirement.
perturbation.law_explanation: Rule 10b-5 prohibits the omission of material facts necessary to make statements made, in light of the circumstances under which they were made, not misleading. By weakening the requirement for prompt notification of defaults, the Company might fail to disclose information critical to investors, leading to a potential violation if investors rely on incomplete or outdated information.

perturbation.original_text: During the period beginning from the Applicable Time and continuing to and including the Remarketing Settlement Date for the Remarketed Securities, not to offer, sell, contract to offer or sell or otherwise dispose of any debt securities of the Company having pricing characteristics similar to the Securities exceeding an aggregate principal amount of $3 billion, except, for the avoidance of doubt, debt securities issued under the Global Medium Term Note Program of Metropolitan Life Global Funding I, Global Medium Term Note Program of MetLife Institutional Funding II, or any commercial paper program of, or sponsored by, the Company or any subsidiaries, without the prior written consent of the Remarketing Agents, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld;
perturbation.changed_text: During the period beginning from the Applicable Time and continuing to and including the Remarketing Settlement Date for the Remarketed Securities, the Company may offer, sell, contract to offer or sell or otherwise dispose of debt securities of the Company having pricing characteristics similar to the Securities, provided it communicates such activities to the Remarketing Agents.
perturbation.explanation: This change replaces a clear restriction on the amount of similar debt securities the company can offer with a vague requirement to simply 'communicate such activities.' This introduces ambiguity by removing a quantifiable limit and potentially allows the company to issue an unlimited amount of similar debt, impacting the value of the Remarketed Securities.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 11 of the Securities Act of 1933 imposes liability for false registration statements. If the company issues a large amount of similar debt securities without properly disclosing the potential impact on the value of the Remarketed Securities in the registration statement, this could be considered a material omission, leading to liability under Section 11.

perturbation.original_text: To make generally available to securityholders of the Company as soon as practicable, but in any event not later than eighteen months after the effective date of the Registration Statement (as defined in Rule 158(c) under the Act), an earnings statement of the Company and its subsidiaries (which need not be audited) complying with Section 11(a) of the Act and the rules and regulations thereunder (including, at the option of the Company, Rule 158);
perturbation.changed_text: To consider making available to securityholders of the Company an earnings statement of the Company and its subsidiaries at some point.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text replaces a firm commitment to provide an earnings statement within a specific timeframe with a vague promise to 'consider making available' such a statement 'at some point'. This makes the delivery of the earnings statement discretionary and removes any binding obligation.
perturbation.law_explanation: Section 10(a)(3) of the Securities Act of 1933 requires that a prospectus used more than nine months after the effective date of the registration statement contain information as of a date not more than sixteen months prior to such use. By removing the obligation to provide an earnings statement within 18 months, the company could be in violation of Section 10(a)(3) if it continues to use the prospectus without updating the financial information.
